title: Better error for re-borrowing &'static mut member from struct as &'static

labels.name: A-diagnostics
labels.description: Area: Messages for errors, warnings, and lints

labels.name: T-compiler
labels.description: Relevant to the compiler team, which will review and decide on the PR/issue.

body:
Given the following code: https://play.rust-lang.org/?version=stable&mode=debug&edition=2021&gist=530228d1c5fdd9bde2c39643ddd8ff9a

```rust
struct Test {
    data: &'static mut [u8],
}

impl Test {
    fn get_data(&self) -> &'static [u8] {
        self.data
    }
}
```

The current output is:

```
error[E0312]: lifetime of reference outlives lifetime of borrowed content...
 --> src/lib.rs:7:9
  |
7 |         self.data
  |         ^^^^^^^^^
  |
  = note: ...the reference is valid for the static lifetime...
note: ...but the borrowed content is only valid for the anonymous lifetime defined here
 --> src/lib.rs:6:17
  |
6 |     fn get_data(&self) -> &'static [u8] {
  |                 ^^^^^
```

Now this might seem strange (it certainly did to me, for a bit) - `data` is `'static`, so why can't I return it as `'static`, and why is the compiler complaining about the lifetime of `&self` here...

The point is, at least I think so, that since we're reborrowing a `&'static mut [u8]`, Rust needs to ensure that the data does not get shared multiple times, even if `'static`. If `data` is made `&'static [u8]` in the struct there is no problem.

The error message, however, does not make this clear, and mentions "mut" or "mutable" nowhere.  Unfortunately I can't suggest a better wording since I'm not 100% certain on terminology.
